40312619.review:
This one was a bit of a nostalgia trip for me, I played this for the first time over a decade ago when I got my very first computer, this actually being the very first PC game I ever played. Obviously being as young and as impatient as I was, I never quite made it past dungeon level 10, but upon rediscovering here I've finally beaten the game and can review it.

Honestly...this game was a heck of a lot more fun and content loaded then I remembered. There are so many different weapons, armor, items, classes, spells...tons of combinations to mix and match, with new enemies that seemed to appear just when you'd think you'd seen them all. The best part is that I didn't get that "Ugh, grindy game" feel whatsoever while playing it. (Of course, I was playing as a summoner-vampire hero, so I was naturally sweeping with ease for most of the floors). For a game of this time, the graphics are pretty nice, the music definitely fitting and the controls made convenient for quick heals/spellcasts.

Despite all of this...I do have a couple of complaints that take away from the game. The first one being knockback - I love the enchantment mechanic because (obviously) it knocks back the foe you're hitting, sometimes making them miss their attack on you. The problem however is that sometimes the knockback will clip the monsters through the wall, where they can hit you but you can't hit them. It's not too game-breaking considering just moving away from the enemy will let him come out, but it does get annoying when you're trying to save your skin by bashing the toughest monster in the group trying to kill you.

Another one (and honestly the only one that really bothered me) was the final floor, or the floor in which you face the boss monster you've been destined to since the beginning of the game. Don't get me wrong, I love that the whole thing was made epic with unique boss monsters following said target. But basically, let me re-enact what happened when I (a summoner-vampire) encountered them; *summons dispelled* *you are blinded* *you are slowed* *you are dead*. All of this within a five second period time. Now of course this isn't supposed to be easy, but...considering the fact that I didn't really have any trouble beating any monsters residing in the previous floors, the difficulty ramp is just ridiculous.

Maybe it was just a terrible class choice and I should have been more sided towards magic or raw power, but in the end I couldn't fight this final boss group no matter what. So in the end, I did what 8 year old me did back then; Die over and over, paying EXP and fame to respawn on the same floor until the boss died. And as soon as he did, I was out and with 0 fame and around 50k+ exp lost. Frankly I didn't care for the whole ending whatsoever, as the whole "retirement / descendant" thing at the end is a New Game + that hardly changes anything from what I can see. It was an achievement though, so I did it anyways :P

TL;DR - Very fun game, tons of class options for how you want to proceed and an endless amount of items, quests and enemies to find / conquer. While endgame could have been much more fun and fair, this did come out in 2005. Great time killer, glad I came back to this :)

34712951.review:
When I started playing this game, I was about 9 years old. This game litteraly was my childhood, but I could only play the trial version and only while I was at my grandparents house. Now that I am 20, and have my own computer, I have decided to pick up the game for nostalgic reasons. After playing it, I was once again hooked. This is the type of game to get if you are looking for a challenge while also just walking around and cutting someone down or fireballing them to death. Now that I am older and know how to play strategically, I have made myself a Mage that regens more mana than I use. 

The game definitely is geared to make you constantly have trouble clearing a floor, but the harder the enemy, the more xp you get, so it balances itself out. Besides, who would want to play a game that is easy to beat? The game also incorporates a special On-Death question. It gives you the choice to revive on the spot at the cost of XP and Fame (my least favorite option), Revives you at a "Nearby Level" for a Cost (It can send you lower in the dungeons), then finally you can choose to drop ALL of your money and be sent 3 levels up in the dungeon (Provides you with a speed run challenge to get your money back), oh and if you aren't fast enough, your money will disappear. Isn't that awesome?

As for graphics, you shouldn't expect very much. The game was released in 2005 and hasn't had any graphic updates that really CHANGED THINGS. But as for me, I do not care if the graphics aren't that of the newer games coming out these days. You can see what is going on and you dont have any trouble understanding what is what.

Story? There isn't really a story to go by other that: "After many days of travel, you've reached the forest town of Grove. On the outskirts of town, and once inside the fiery dungeon gates, you'll find fame, adventure and fortune." Then the big quest that you have to complete by going very deep into the dungeon to defeat a big boss monster. My game gave me a boss on level 51 of the dungeon.

Overall, I think everyone should play this game, its as fun as the new games but has been around much longer. Its a game that if you haven't played it, then you dont have a childhood. So what are you waiting for? Choose your FATE and get to playing!

After level 40 there is a scaling problem with magic. The spells stop getting much stronger. Early game summoning is very strong. However, the game is so repetetive, that I beat it and continued playing for 13 or so dungeon levels without even knowing I beat the "final boss". It's a really good time killer and can run on any computer purchased in the past 10 years very well. The soundtrack is really nice and it really hasn't aged to terribly over the years.

[b]TL;DR[/b]
Well worth the money; the game has aged very well over the years. A requirement for any Steam library.

Fun

This is a classic and helped make me love video games honestly. It's just a fun and an awesome dungeon crawler. Casual and truly overlooked. 
Worth every penny.

32558418.review: played it for hours as a a kid just grinding now im a grown ass man just grinding all over again. a must play in my book

32420703.review:
Back around 2006 to 2008 I played the heck out of this game. It was released during a time when no one was really making ARPG's anymore. You had Diablo 2, several years old at that point, Titan's Quest, and not much else. One of the few good games to come from publisher Wildtangent, I sunk many hours into this game and beat it multiple times with different play styles. 
You can play as a summoner, as a mage, as a warrior, ranger, or any hybrid really, because there are no classes, simply skills and attribute points. It is actually a very open ended system that lets you make different kinds of builds.
While it definitely does not hold up today against modern titles like Torchlight 1/2, Path of Exile, Grim Dawn, and others it is still a good diversion for fans of the genre who want to experience something new.

32268402.review: This was my favourite game growing up, and playing it now, its still amazing. The dungeons are randomly generated, youre free to make your character to suit whatever your playstyle is, so its replay value is quite high. I f you want the best old school dungeon crawler, look no further.

32244007.review: Juego Dungeon que marcó mi infancia al más puro estilo de Diablo 3

32078129.review:
Before Torchlight, there was Fate. A dungeon-crawler RPG where you slay hordes of monsters, help the townsfolk and get items, gold and fame.

Pros:
1. Diablo-like: As my favorite RPGs of all time is Diablo, this game brings a very similar gameplay.
2.  Dungeon levels: while some seem very short or very long, the layouts, theme and monsters were pretty awesome and never boring(in my opinion)
3. Items are pretty basic but dual-wielding Wakizashis was super fun
4. Pet companions: Being able to load up your pet and send it town to sell your abundance of junk items for gold was very resourceful. Not to mention having a 2nd source of damage if you got surrounded
5. The music in this game was pretty chill and welcoming. Though I would've preferred some rock or some metal 



Cons: 
1. While the pet companion was helpful, the lack of selection was pretty sad. Cat or Dog is nice but would've been epic to walk around with a wolf or even a Falcon.
2. While being to change your pet into whatever monster by fish, I was really sold on the idea. Seemed like a waste of time to just sit at a fishing hole, trying to find those rare fish that give permanent changes or huge stat increases. It just wasn't my cup of tea.

Overall, this game is super fun, child friendly as there isn't really anything gory or inappropiate for younger ages.

32056581.review: One of the best dugeon crawlers around! Not intensive on your pc at all. The game is a bit old with graphcis that aren't the best, but I recommend this game for sure!

30605433.review:
The classic aRPG from the same developers as Torchlight. I played this game when it first came out, and picked up the Steam copy later on. This is a pseudo-port to more modern PCs. The cartoony graphics hold up well. It's a fun little loot-fest, though not terribly deep. It has good difficulty options, and is basically color-blind friendly. However, it's mouse-and-keyboard controls only, and mouse is absolutely required. Controls are not remappable, and there's no included switch-access. Sound is a good fit for the game, but doesn't provide any information. Anything spoken by the narrator is also presented as text, so one just misses some ambience without sound. 
It's infinitely replayable thanks to procedurally generated maps and the descendent character new game, although if you enjoy it, you'll likely just move onto the next game in the franchise.

29935102.review:
My goodness, I remember this being the only WildTangent game I found to be VERY fun. I spent all my free play tokens on it. A looooong time later, it's still fun.

PROS: simple, casual gameplay
"easy to pick up hard to master" sorta thing, but in the sense of building your character and synergising different abilities
Finds a way to make anything and everything useful to some degree, and you'll find yourself digging into several stats at once to make a build that holds its own
Super intelligent UI and menu management, something essentially nonexistant in the modern era

NEUTRAL: Isometric

CONS: definetly a dated game, not in the way Half-Life was the revolutionary FPS game but more of the "old gem that's outshadowed by other games, yet retaining really cool features that modern games have lost"
Less-that-helpful tutorial system, it teaches you the very basics but unless you're willing to look at all the niches of all the stats and find out information for yourself in the dungeon, you'll miss out. Seriously, it took me until floor 8 to realize that I could run away from a strike and have it miss my hitbox.

OVERALL: 82/100, has charm and is endless fun but is relatively simple. Some shortcomings here and there, but most are overshadowed by good excecution by the developers.

do note that this does hold a nostalgic place in my heart, but not enough to keep me playing if I didn't enjoy it. Even non-fans on RPGs will like it, and 2 hours (steam's max refund playtime) is more than enough to grasp a general feel of the game.

No game has ever made me more excited to get a new spell or new piece of gear. A true classic

29644017.review: This game was my first RPG. Actually, the demo of this game was my first RPG, and let me tell you I sunk hundreds of hours into the demo alone. You could probably find better games of this nature out today (some of the developers of this game went on to make Torchlight and Torchlight II), but if you don't mind an older dungeon crawler with an infinite amount of procedurally generated content (for dungeon levels, item names and stats; you won't find wonky No Man's Sky creations wandering the levels of the dungeon) to sink some time in to, I highly recommend this game. If you want to play a simple addicting game that doesnt require you learn all the ins and outs of "damage per second" and secondary "elemental" damage systems then this is what you're looking for. On the off chance that you're a parent looking for a game for their kid to play, maybe to start them on RPGs, this would be a good start, with lovable characters, cute pets, and nothing too frightening for young eyes this game is fantastic.

29642272.review: Wow I never knew they had this on steam. Bought it and as soon as I hit play, the nostalgia kicked in.  This game may be old, but it sure as hell is one of the best of its kind to this day. You never get bored as nothing is ever the same in each playthrough. Every time you play, the dungeon floors are different, the monsters are different, the loot you get is different, and the quests you get is different. So many ways to build your character as well. Buy this if you like RPGs and dungeon crawlers. You won't be disappointed with this.

29642053.review: Playing this game when it came out was mind-blowing to me. It was such an addicting Action-Adventure, RPG, and Dungeon Crawler that I feel it was a little ahead of its time. 29179322.review:
Almost really good. The actual gameplay was fun. Simple hack 'n' smash through a dungeon, with customizability. And despite many ways to customize, it isn't complicated. 

Why the thumbs down? This is Bag Space - The Game. I spent more of my time doing inventory management than actually playing the darn game. Not only that, but while your pet is selling for you, tabbing out of the game to read news pauses the game so you can't multitask. It also doesn't have mods, so I can't just add bag space in easily. Seriously, the game-play is fun. The gearing is a bit annoying, but workable. Bloody hell the bag space issue though, ugh! 

Yes, the game is 10 years old. Yes, it clearly inspired Torchlight and was likely inspired by Diablo (which are both excellent). Still, I wanted to play a hack 'n' smash, not Bag Space. If you have the patience for that, you can snag this cheapish and get a pretty easy perfect game for your Steam profile though. Sorry, being 10 years old doesn't forgive the bag space nonsense.

27411416.review:
This game was basically my childhood, and is still fun and addictive. There are many, many hours of varied gameplay available and the graphics aren't even that bad for today (Just... don't expect much out of it. It's no Diablo III). It plays like a dungeon crawler should - very variably - and is NOT a walk in the park. Overall, here's what I'd say are the pros and cons.

Pros:
+Varied monsters
+Varied weapons
+Good graphics for the time period
+Large amount of content
+Difficulty scales well (Easy is actually easy, while hard is actually very hard)
+No overpowered items or spells
+A nice cartoony look
+Very, very easy to mod with a little knowledge of Javascript and Photoshop or Gimp

Cons:
-Faces look kinda messed up, limited character appearance customization
-Less than stellar translations (From what I hear... I do not speak French or Spanish fluently enough to try Fate in either)
-Occasionally annoying sounds (I'm definitely talking about the cat or dog. I'd recommend getting a fish to permanently transform them as quickly as possible)
-Point and click style can get boring
-Some... creative names can come up for bosses and for items (Like "Zulgthar's Holy Bec de Corbin of Spite" or "Og the Facesmasher").
-Lack of interesting spells (They're the pretty cut and dry "Fireball" spells, "Summon ______" spells, and "Raise defense" spells typical of this genre. The only really interesting ones are the meteor one and the one that turns enemies to your side.)
-Not for everyone. There are free trials for this game - use them. Decide if you like it or not before buying. It is dated, after all.
-No online multiplayer of any kind
-Not many in-game settings options
-A bit of a confusing fame system. (You get skill points to spend for becoming more famous)
-Some logical fallacies (Fishing in lava)

Overall, even though numerically there are more negatives, the positives far outweigh the negatives for this game. If you haven't given this classic a try, go ahead and get the demo then buy the full game if you like it. I know I did, and I know that I've sunken hundreds of thousands of hours into this immersive fantasy dungeon-crawler. (I just got it for Steam, though)

26305228.review:
Oh FATE... It was one of the first, if not the first aRPG I've ever played! I used to love this game... After replaying it, I can tell i'm not impressed, there are many things done wrong, there are many bugs in this version and the translation is utterly terrible!

Here's the list of issues with the game.


1. Language locked to your System Language.

Since I don't have Windows 7 Ultimate, it's impossible for me to change my game to english... I'm forced to play in French, which, I dislike to do, first of all. Also if you try to modify the language of the game by playing with files, you will most likely break it at some point and the game will just crash. Then, on top of that, the translation is really rubbish, nothing makes sense!


2. The translation to french (and possibly the spanish one too) are bad.

The names of the monsters or items are hilarious to look at, because they all look like "Hammer of of fire of the the great Tahl bat" and the likes...


3. The voice acting is poor. (French)

The english voice acting is fine, but the laughs and the quotes from the narrator in french are really cringe...


4. Bugs.

Well, first of all, if you launch the game and click anywhere during it's loading, it crashes your computer! It did that on 3 of my computers, all desktops. Pretty much, the game gets stuck with the in-game cursor + the computer mouse at the same time, everything you click does nothing and CTRL+ALT+DLT doesn't alt-tab you. You have to restart your computer!


5. Broken achievement.

Yep, the achievements for Large Chests is broken if you're game is not in english. It's impossible to get it, unless you modify game files. Boo!


6. Looting issues.

Items names are very hard to click on and they stack on top of each other, You always have your inventory clustered with junk you did not even want to loot because of that.


7. Game Balance.

Griffons dies in 2 hit, they're huge! However, rats summoned by a same level Vampire will tank more hits, what?

Also, Yeti deals insane damage and are relatively tanky. Where some mobs deals less damage and dies in 2-3 hits.

Melee + Shield is somewhat weak. You have to split your skill points in 1 type of weapon (for example swords), points in block and points in critical strike. For example, summoners or rangers, only have to put their points in 1 or 2 of them, so they're alot better in that aspect. And even for stat points! If you're a summoner, all into Vitality (and enough magic to cast your favorite summon), because nothing else is worth it. Ranger and melee though, you need 3 to 4 stats! You hit very rarely with melee or range unless you have lots of Dexterity and Attack(accuracy) on gear. Mages always hit, how fair.

Also with melee, or range, you're stuck with mostly the same type of damage (slashing, piercing etc), since you have to spec into a certain kind of weapon. So if a monster resists 100% of it, good luck! But if you're a mage, no problem. Summoners have every types of summons and caster mages have Fire, Ice, Poison, Lightning spells with 0 penalty for using every elements, because all you need is "Attack magic!".

8. Frame Rate issues.

The Steam version has horrible frame rate issues! I've played FATE on multiple computers before and it always ran fluently, even on my Pentium III and on my cheap i5. But my gaming PC with an i5 that maxes out almost any games, lags as soon as there are 4-5 mobs on the screen... Were talking about 10-15 fps drops. So, scratch playing a summoner if you're unlucky enough to get this Frame Rate bug i'm having. I tried a few fixes, but nothing seemed to help.


9. Gambling.

Gambling in this game is... Poor. First of all, you get tons of stuff that you cannot even use, because they have very high requirements or requires alot of fame. Then you get bases that are still very weak later in the game. Also, the price sometimes doesn't seem to matter at all. I've bought items at 10,000 gold that were good and were cyan (the best before unique items) and I've bought items at 800,000 gold tags that were pruple (the worst kind of magic items) with an horrible stat (even negative stats!). It's like it's 100% random when you roll your item. You could pay 1 million gold and end up with an item that gives you -19% life and nothing else.

I understand it's gambling, but this looks like a true random item generator.


Overall, I like the game, but compared to Torchlight or pretty much any other aRPG, it's just a bit too unbalanced to be enjoyable. It's got broken achievements and bugs too. Looting is wonky and if you're computer is not in english, you just can't set the game to english, if you try to modify files, you will most likely break the game at some point.

------------------------------------

UPDATE: I've contacted their support and they refuse to fix it, they say it's Steam's fault when it's not.

26106776.review:
Oh my goodness. I can't believe I didn't see this game was on Steam. I LOVED This game as a kid. We got it with a whole lot of demos on a computer we bought a long time ago. The demo only lets you go to the 3rd floor of the Dungeon. Time for some personal backstory:

It was some time around 2008. I was in Elementary School still. (4th grade I think). I didn't drink enough water on a daily basis, so my bladder got infected. I started to pee blood, so I motioned for my teacher to come out in the hallway while I tell her the embarrasing news. My Mom came and picked me up. We went to my doctor's office (It was sort of like a clinic. It's hard to explain).

The doctor took me in, and told me I was going to have to get blood drawn which sent me into a panic. I had never had my blood drawn before, and I HATED needles (What kid doesn't?). So, the Doctor came in with this huge needle and stuck it into my arm. It hurt like crap. Afterwards I was really shaken up, and we ususally got toys or video games after we go to the doctors/dentists (I was into Legos at the time, so I got Lego sets for the dentist). That day, we drove to Walmart, and went to the PC games section.

It felt good to pick up that game, and put it into the cart. My mom even let me get some candy on the way out. (Some sour candy. I LOVE sour candy). Of course, I couldn't play it right as I got home. Mom had to do the checking account. So, my brother and I went outside and we sat down on a matress that was sitting outside. (It was out in my Grandma's backyard. My grandma lives right next to us. I live on a farm, btw.)

I rushed home soon, and heard that sweet sound the bank software makes when you log out; A really crunchy CHA-CHING!!! So, I sat down and put the disk into the computer. Like I said earleir, it was a long time ago and computers were super slow back in the day. So, I had to wait until the game finished installing.

Finally! It finished! Oh, that sweet song that plays at the beginning. Captain O'Kane. That song captures the epicness of this game.

The game is called Fate, you know that. You're a young adventurer with your Animal Companion (Dog or cat. You can change it later...). You arrive in the town of Grove, where the entrence to a large dungeon stand, beckoning the daring adventurers in.

You start off basic. You don't have any armor, but you do have a hachet. (Axe). I'm going to do a walkthrough on my YouTube channel, so you can get the jist of the starting.

You  can fish, too! So I recommend that you buy a fishing rod and fish to your heart's content. You can sell those fish or feed them to your pet. Each fish has different effects. Let's say you feed your pet a fish, and it turns them into a spider!! All the fish you get can turn your animal companion into a Dungeon Creature, but it will stay loyal to you and fight for you.

You can chose what kind of skill you want to use. Personally I use the sword and shield the most, but I've used magic and bows too.

It's good because you can use Magic and be a swordsman, or use magic and be an archer.  Magic, magic, magic.

You can get quests from certain people around town. I strongly suggest you take the quests, because they pay off well.

The main goal of the game is to find the boss of the Dungeon (It tells you at the beginning. It's always randomized too), and get rich!

I haven't actually gotten that far, but I've been to floor 100 and beyond. Which is almost as good I guess.

I STRONGLY recommend this game. It's a steal for $7.99 . I hope you liked this review of it, and be sure to find my channel on YouTube so you can watch gameplay of it, if you're not sure about it. Thanks for reading.

25307170.review:
[h1]아쉬운 타격감, 다양한 몬스터의 FATE 초기작[/h1]

Wild Tangent 에서 2005년 발매한 디아블로 형식의 롤플레잉 게임입니다. 스팀에만 동일제작사의 FATE게임이 4종이 있습니다. 연식이 있는 게임이기 때문에 현재 게임과 비교해보면 모자란 점이 많이 보입니다. 

참고로 FATE의 제작사인 Wild Tangent에서 근무했었던 Travis Baldree 가 Torchlight 제작에도 참여하여 Torchlight 와 시스템적으로 유사한 점이 많습니다. 모든 무기를 주력으로 다뤄본 거는 아니지만, Torchlight 와는 다르게 Hack & Slash 게임의 중요 요소인 타격감이  좋지 않았습니다. 그렇다고 게임의 퀘스트가 다양하고 레벨링 요소가 재미있는 것도 아니면서, 단순한 Dungeon Crawler 방식이라 게임의 재미도 별로였습니다. 좋았던 점은 등장하는 몬스터의 다양성이었습니다. 

같은 제작자의 게임인 Torchlight 1편과 매우 유사하며, FATE 시리즈 보다는 시스템적으로 발전되서 나온 [b]Torchlight 시리즈를 플레이 하시길 추천[/b]합니다.

25046927.review:
Before I begin this review, I'd like to note that I had never played this game before. Everything was new, and the only thing I knew about it was that it was an apparent classic that a streamer I watch occaisonally played once. So here I am with the steam version instead of the hard copy or the download from the old website. So, you're asking, what do I think of this game?

It's pretty charming and entertaining even in 2016, 11 years after release

In case you couldn't tell, FATE is a dungeon crawler. Same routine, battle through different floors of this "mysterious dungeon" that happens to be the main heart for everything that lives and breathes. Everyone knows about this one dungeon, and everyone depends on it for a living. Everyone lives the dungeon, everyone breathes the dungeon, and your the hero who will fight through all 50 floors and blah blah blah... you get the routine.

However, even though it may be mediocre, you can NEVER find a crawler like this these days. It's all about "Pay 2 Win" and "Fighting angry robot sharks with chainsaws for hands" and "Swords that are bigger than the protagonist themselves." Sadly, FATE may be one of the last of it's kind. For this, I can look over the mediocre-ness, because this is a classic, and I highly recommend it. You just can't find a game like this nowadays! =(

24808254.review:
Pros
- Has most of the good things about Diablo and Diablo II, though it's quite an obvious protege.
- Gold is automatically picked up, yay.
- Nice mindless game to play through if you're not looking for much variety.

Neutral
- Not too crazy about the art style, but it's not bad either.

Cons
- Generic dungeon crawling with quests on about every level. Kill this, retrieve item, return to town, repeat. There's no originality here.
- The skill tree isn't very interesting, and isn't really a tree at all.
- Dungeons are often needlessly filled with many dead ends, requiring a looottt of time to backtrack overall.
- It's needlessly difficult to heal at the beginning for some reason; you generate not even one single hit point when out of combat and health potions aren't always easy to come by or buy early on.
- The voice acting for when traps are sprung, etc. is a bit annoying, as well as low quality.
- This game requires a lot of grinding to be able to defeat monsters; the yeti on levels 10 and 11 is way overpowered compared to the rest of the monsters leading up to that point, and the ogres starting on level 12 are sudden, too.
- Magic casting is ridiculously slow at the beginning, almost comically so.
- Incredibly repetitive content; the quests are for randomly generated items or to kill random beasts, and always just for a formulaic reward in experience, fame, and gold.
- The sound effects are also very redundant; every single attack by an enemy has only their one designated sound effect, so enemies that attack quickly sound super annoying. The game is also too loud and ear-piercing even on a low sound effects volume.
- There are many miscellaneous bugs with the game, such as my dog sometimes appearing over gaps where he cannot walk such as ascending and descending stairs, and the hitboxes for picking up items are some of the worst I've ever seen.

Basically, I recommend this game only as a mindless bit of entertainment to play through. There's nothing very defining or special about it.

So while I only have 11.8 hours total in this game, (and have 100%'d it in that time, for those achievement hunters out there) I probably sank HUNDREDS of hours into this same game under WildTangent's own distribution method 8-9 years ago. This is a pretty slow-paced, single-player lite version of Diablo, if you want a TL;DR of what to expect.

If it's not obvious, the game was released in 2005, and even with that being said some of what it offers still holds up pretty well. FATE: Traitor Souls is probably worth picking up if you enjoyed this game at all.

Side Note: This was probably one of my very first videogames, would work really well as a present to a kid, as it's super simple, really family-friendly, and easy enough mechanically that even a technologically impaired adult could get some good fun out of it.

Me:
Sees FATE on steam

*A few days later

Finds disc copy
Unistalls steam-bought version and installs the one I bought years ago
Works
Graphics are better
Runs smoother
Has cheats

$9.99 on WT or play it occasionally with coins earned from subscribing to WT *not recommended

Even aside from that the game is a good play. It has many items that can be found and a potentially infinite amount of levels to explore due to procedural generation. There are bosses among the monsters. There are quests along with a fame and a leveling system. There's a pet which will follow you, fish you can feed it to change its form as well as an inventory for it in case yours fills up.

There's still a bunch of stuff to do 11 years later. 7/10

22852930.review:
As an old-school gamer it's hard to admit that this great game flew under my radar.

TL: DR- Buy it.

Imagine a mix between Diablo-style gameplay ( random generated dungeons) and the quirky look of a Link game.

You have Fate!

This game lets you mold and blend a character and his / her attributes / skills etc however you like. Want a Wizard that dual-welds swords? Want a pole-ax welding warrior that can casts fireballs? Almost ( as far as I can tell) any combo of character is possible. How is this possible? Well...patience..

See, as you progress through the game, you can always go back and clear a level of the dungeon again. This is grindy yes, but allows for those players with the patience and resolve to make a truely badass character. If you want to play through without back-tracking that's possible too.

 You also have a "pet"; and this pet fills the role of protecter and Mule very well. You can, apparently, upgrade your pet by feeding it but I've yet to get that far.

 Very fun game so far. I will update review as I make progress. I bought this game for $8, and it's cash well spent!


 Rivscore 88/ 100

22714446.review: This game was one of the first games I purchased for PC on the internet, back in the early 00's. It's a great dungeon crawler and plays similarly to Diablo. The art-style is a little cutesy, but still, the models and graphic design are well fleshed out. The different levels and monsters are well designed and always have a central theme to tie everything together. The ability to have a pet is a nice feature, and the use of different fish to transform your pet into a monster to help you in battle gives the fishing mini-game a good reason to be played. The different abilities and skill trees are fun to try and different builds keep the game interesting.

22711437.review:
Задорный мультяшный hack'n'slash в лучших традициях диаблы. Говорю «в лучших традициях» — подразумеваю, что это её клон. 

Основная особенность — тотальный и абсолютный рандом, что и покорило моё сердце. Каждый уровень подземелья сгенерирован случайно, причём не как во второй части близзардовской времяубивалки — с заранее заданными шаблонами, а совершенно от балды. Выход на следующий уровень в шаге от входа? Да пожалуйста. Ни одного монстра за 10 минут хождений по лабиринтам, зато потом три десятка в одной комнате? Не вопрос. И так далее.

Эта истинная рандомность, которую можно смело назвать игровым кредо, распространяется и на предметы: лук с плюсом к блокированию щитом или копьё с бонусом к владению арбалетом — обычные артефакты из карманов каждого первого гоблина. Просто волшебно.

И ещё важное замечание — эта игра бесконечна. Да, у вас есть что-то вроде главного квеста от местного Гэндальфа: нужно забить какого-то опять же рандомного дядьку на каком-то разумной глубины уровне, но спускаться всё ниже и ниже можно без конца. Монстры становятся толще, артефакты легендарнее, а мешки под глазами темнее. Что, 4 часа ночи, а завтра на работу? Ну ещёёёё пять минууууточек!

I snagged this game from a Humble Bundle, mostly for nostalgia purposes; it was one of the first video games my family owned, and my brother and I played it obsessively. 21592806.review:
Edit de mon eval après avoir fini le jeu et tous les achievement : ne pas acheter à part pour des raisons de nostalgie, c'est (en 2016) une bouse, remplie de bug, de problemes de gameplay et d'une difficulté en dent de scie
Alors a n'acheter qu'en promotion, et uniquement si vous adorez le style hack & slash / dungeon crawler, et les vieux jeux pourris

En résumé, il s'agit d'un croisement entre Diablo et Torchlight. 
Le jeu a vieilli bien sur mais reste agréable de prime abord dans l'ensemble, avec toutefois de grosses lacunes qui se dévoilent au fil des heures de jeu et le rendent énervant, voire impraticable

A mon sens il mérite un 5/10 au mieux à l'heure actuelle. Il mériterait facilement une évaluation positive et 2 ou 3 points de plus si les dev avaient un peu réfléchi a certaines mécaniques... des détails parfois, mais ces détails font la différence


Points neutres
- jeu pas prise de tête : un donjon qui se descend étage par étage, et on ne fait que taper des monstres (le seul truc qui brise la monotonie ce sont les quêtes qui obligent a revenir au village de temps en temps). Pas d'histoire, rien. On tape, on tape, on ramasse des objets, on tape, on meurt.
- gestion de la mort punitive : mourir coute cher, soit en temps pour remonter dans le donjon, soit en argent, ou expérience... pour moi c'est un bon point (mais ca s'ajoute d'un autre coté aux points négatifs, ci dessous)
- une gestion du personnage suffisamment customisée pour pouvoir avoir plusieurs styles différents (arme / bouclier, deux mains, magie, mixte...) D'un autre coté le jeu ne proposant qu'un seul personnage et pas de classe différente c'est un minimum, mais au moins ce minimum est présent
Seulement la aussi ce point est en fait negatif car on se rend compte a la fin du jeu que certains styles sont impossibles a jouer (corps a corps notamment on se fait one shot par des monstres surpuissants, alors que la magie est très puissante)

Points negatifs
- ennemis qui fuient. Pour moi la mecanique est bonne et logique, mais elle pose probleme : le jeu ne gérant pas les collisions, on ne peut pas courir après un monstre pour le taper, sans subir des ralentissements du personnage empechant de taper. il faut contourner l'ennemi, utiliser un sort pour courir plus vite, ou la plupart du temps le laisser s'enfuir
La mécanique n'étant pas poussée jusqu'au bout, ca ne gene en fait absolument pas de le laisser s'enfuir : il ne regagne pas de point de vie, ne prévient pas d'autres monstres...
Au final aucun intéret a part ennuyer le joueur

- la gestion de l'inventaire a la diablo 2, copiée / collée. Ca peut ajouter un élément réaliste que certains aimeront mais la aussi, au final ca n'a aucun intérêt a part ennuyer le joueur. Comme dans Torchlight on peut envoyer le pet en ville pour vendre, régulièrement, donc a quoi bon limiter autant l'inventaire ?

- a propos de pet, celui ci est a peu près inutile. Les miaulement incessants (j'ai choisi un chat...) et les phrases spammées "votre animal s'enfuit" énervent très vite. pour une raison inconnue le pet a toujours l'aggro, les monstres le taperont en premier. Il sera donc pratiquement en permanence bas en vie... Pourtant il effectue des dommages conséquents mais avec la gestion de l'inventaire et le fait qu'on ne peut le guérir qu'avec des potions, c'est une mécanique encore ici anti jeu

- la gestion totalement WTF de l'argent en jeu et de la qualité des objets. Le prix de vente / achat des objets est en effet totalement mal (voire pas du tout) géré 
A la D2 la encore, vous aurez au niveau 1 chez des marchands du stuff de niveau 50. Si on veut acheter de l'équipement il faut relancer plusieurs fois le jeu jusqu'a trouver quelque chose de son niveau / finances
Pire : a propos de finance. En pêchant (accessible pour 200po dès le niveau 1) j'ai rapidement eu un baton légendaire vendu 800 000 pièces d'or - on démarre avec 500. J'ai looté ce même baton, vendu 100 fois le prix des autres équipements, deux autres fois : hop, or infini avant le niveau 10, sans raison. Ca gache totalement la raison même de ramasser l'équipement et de le vendre quand on a sur soi 1000 fois l'or nécessaire ? 

- gestion des affrontements aléatoire : souvent on a des monstres présentés un par un, qu'on éclate facilement, puis on se fait surprendre par 20 truc qui vous sautent dessus et vous tuent
L'inventaire faisant qu'on ne peut pas vraiment transporter ni gérer beaucoup de potions, c'est assez ennuyeux. 
A l'inverse on devient assez vite immortel pour peu qu'on mette la main sur le bon équipement ... 

- quêtes aléatoires aussi : en general les quêtes rapportent énormément en argent, expérience, réputation... ca vaut vraiment le coup de les faire c'est un bon point. Mais contrairement a torchlight, les PNJ donnent des quêtes choisies aléatoirement dans les prochains niveau du donjon - si vous êtes au lv 10 on vous donnera du lv 10, 11 ou 12 ... Or étant donné ce que rapportent ces quêtes on se retrouve a devoir recharger le jeu jusqu'a avoir les quêtes (3 maximum, c'est trop peu ! ) correspondant au niveau actuel qu'on est en train de faire. Encore une mécanique à la base bonne qui est gachée par un élement inutile

- pour un des achievement, en jouant en francais, on doit carrément aller modifier des fichiers du jeu : l'achievement est "en dur" dans le code et ne tient pas compte de la localisation dans une langue autre que l'anglais ! Ce type de probleme se retrouve dans d'autres choses dans le jeu, par exemple j'ai eu une quête gachée parceque mon inventaire était plein 
Devoir trouver un objet dans le donjon - le faire ramasser par le pet parceque inventaire plein... Quete non validée. Impossible a revalider, meme en reposant l'objet par terre et en le reprenant. j'ai fini par y arriver en juste la prenant dans le curseur et la reposant dans l'inventaire. Conclusion ? le jeu n'est pas foutu de prendre en compte une validation de base par l'animal au lieu du personnage principal, la plupart des éléments sont codés en dur, et si on sort un petit peu de ce que le développeur a prévu, ca ne fonctionne plus ! 

- enchantements, sur le meme principe que torchlight. mais coutant chacun le prix de l'objet, donc inutilisables : pourquoi risquer de supprimer toutes les capacités de son objet, en payant un prix en plus prohibitif, pour gagner un mini bonus au mieux ? 

- a la fin du jeu la difficulté explose d'un coup sans prevenir comme si le jeu voulait gonfler artificiellement la durée de vie

Enfin techniquement il arrive que le jeu soit une pourriture : j'ai rencontré des cas ou, une quête faisant apparaitre un boss et un groupe de monstres tres polygonés, le jeu n'arrivait plus a suivre et passait a moins de 10 FPS lorsqu'on rentrait en contact avec ces monstres. S'enfuit mort rapide a laquelle on ne peut rien faire et une quête impossible a réaliser. 
En 2016, avec un PC de joueur, le jeu ralenti et bug, qu'est ce que ca devait être en 2005 ...


Je fais référence a torchlight car il y a énormément de similarités, mais en tout point torchlight est meilleur / mieux équilibré. Alors évidemment, ce jeu est sorti avant, donc c'est tout a fait normal. En 2005 c'était probablement un super jeu. Mais en 2016 pourquoi se forcer à acheter un jeu ancien si beaucoup d'autres, meilleurs, sont disponible ?

20822030.review: Hope you like [strike]rolling boulders up hills[/strike] grinding with monotonous combat mechanics, because that's what the [i]FATE[/i] games are all about.  Maybe they weren't that bad for their time, but there's no reason to play them anymore (assuming there ever was).  They get old quickly, and there's hardly anything to distinguish them from each other (they're so similar, I have no problem just copying and pasting the same review on each of the three that I own).  Moreover, there's nothing to distinguish them from the more recent [i]Torchlight[/i] (not surprising, given that the Runic Games team includes ex-WildTangent devs), except [i]Torchlight[/i] is better in every respect: better graphics, better combat, and better performance (despite being developed for Pentium systems, the [i]FATE[/i] games still manage to overheat my Core 2 Duo gaming laptop even while running at 800x640 with minimal graphics quality).  Want to play a dungeon crawler?  Play [i]Torchlight[/i].  Already played [i]Torchlight[/i]?  You're still probably better off replaying it, or playing its sequel (disclaimer: I have not).  If you really insist on getting a [i]FATE[/i] game, I suggest starting with [i]Cursed King[/i], since it at least adds a little more character customization and a much-needed button to quickly swap weapon loadouts.

19120299.review:
Gameplay-wise it's good enough at being a hack'n'slash ARPG I suppose (it copies Diablo profoundly enough to comply with the genre's standards), some mechanics such as being able to have your pet sell your junk are pretty neat (saves you A LOT of town portals) but the absolute absence of any story or development is too mindnumbing for me to enjoy this.
The only hint of an objective is a guy in town who reminds me that a boss awaits in level 46. Who's the boss? Why am I supposed to fight it? Silly me for wanting to know. It seems everything between starting a new game and facing the boss is just an endless stream of randomly generated (and thus painfully soulless) fetch quests that follow the exact same formula over and over. Not that much fun.
Now I haven't really played much of this so I might be wrong and maybe some sort of a story kicks in later but even if that's the case it's still a rubbish design decision to give the player no sense of direction or motivation right away.
Also the game looks dated (though some environments do look quite compelling) AND runs like [i]a bottom[/i], but that's really just a minor problem compared to the dullness.

So while this is not a horrible game by any means, I can't really recommend it to anyone, maybe save for ARPG enthusiasts who want to try every game of the genre that ever came out.

Just play Torchlight instead. I can't think of anything FATE does better.

18870756.review:
Hey all,
I recently tried to play FATE after upgrading to Windows 10, but was experiencing the "Application error" issue. The solution that worked for me was to start the game in window-mode and make sure that the window-width and -height (including the border) were small enough to fit inside the screen’s set resolution.

To start the game in window-mode go to "C:\ProgramData\WildTangent\FateSteam\Persistent" on your computer, open the "config.dat" file with Notepad, and change “FULLSCREEN:1” to:
FULLSCREEN:0

Also, ensure that “WINDOWWIDTH” and “WINDOWHEIGHT” in the config file are set to something that will allow the application window, including the border, to fit within your screen resolution. For example my brother’s screen resolution is 1366x768, so we put our values at: 
WINDOWWIDTH:1366
WINDOWHEIGHT:725

For some reason, if the window is set to a size where even the border is to the outside of the screen, it creates a graphical issue where the gameplay is located in a small box to the left corner within the application window. 

I hope this helps someone else. Cheers!

18141472.review:
The FATE series is definitely starting to show its age now.  But if you’re a fan of classic dungeon crawlers or are interested in exploring the history of Diablo-clones, it’s well-worth checking out.  

Among other things, it used to be a popular Diablo-clone in its day, attracted a dedicated modding community around it for a number of years.  Plus it might especially interest fans of the Torchlight series, because the different developers behind Diablo II and FATE are also the same people who eventually got together to co-found Runic Games and made Torchlight.  

Not only was Torchlight directly influenced by Diablo II in that sense.  But it likewise inherited a lot of features from FATE.  Sure, you could point out that even long before FATE and Torchlight, dungeon crawlers such as Nethack had pets, too.  But FATE was really the first one to introduce pets into the gameplay in a Diablo-type game, and to give them features such as their own inventory interface, so they could carry some of your loot, and at the click of a button be sent to town to cash-it-in for you.  Plus it introduced some other new things to that gameplay too, such as being able to fish for loot at fishing holes scattered throughout the game.  That’s not to mention it also came up with how the user-interfaces look and work for all of those things.  Other than maybe give them a lick of paint and a tweak or two, Torchlight barely changed many of those things at all when it inherited them from FATE.  

For better or worse, FATE also influenced Torchlight’s toon-like style.  That conspicuously didn’t come from Diablo II.  And it’s a design-choice which might put off some players at first.  But it can also make FATE a perfect game with which to introduce younger players to Diablo-clones if you have kids.  That certainly proved to be the case in my household when my kid was growing up.

Despite how child-friendly and lighthearted FATE might look on its surface, once you get into it, it’s also still quite an expertly made and solid Action-RPG deep-down.  In that respect it’s still a blast to play today, because that well-tuned gameplay it had beneath its surface as a Diablo-clone is still there in an ageless sort of way.   

You also needn't worry about having to get the whole FATE series.  The sequels mostly just add some additional content and include previous content in them.  Otherwise they essentially play and feel the same.  I happen to prefer the first FATE game a bit for my own nostalgic reasons.  But you’re good to jump into the series wherever you want.

Anyway, the bottom-line is the FATE series might not be for everybody.  But I’d still heartily recommend it to any fans of classic dungeon crawlers and Diablo-clones, young or old. 

(Note:  This review also replaces a previous review I did for the FATE series.  It was a mixed review just to alert buyers to an issue it used to have being unable to run under Windows 10 for some users, despite trying many popular workarounds to fix that.  But as near as I can tell, it no longer has that issue.  So that means I can finally give FATE its real due with my new review here.  Not only that, but on Steam it also has more resolution-options now than it used to.  So it’s not only fixed, but it’s also improved.  That’s another real plus.)

18138121.review: A cute and adequate diablo clone but without the capacity for multiplayer -- which frankly is a standard of games like this ever since... well, Diablo. I got sucked in initially by it's subtle charm and my affinity for the genre, but frankly stayed with it to beat the game on a grudge. The loot system is flawed in that the majority of gear is unusable without certain stat requirements -- for example, to wear plate mail you'd literally have to win the game more than once, perhaps several times. That frankly is ludicrous, considering my character was literally defined as a hero of great reknown who was DRIPPING in strength-giving gear and focused on developing strength... what, is plate mail made of depleted uranium in this world? This is just one example... the vast majority of equipment you find or see in stores is reserved for people who (somehow) have the time and facination to remain on the hamster wheel. I hate-played this game just to see what was waiting for me when I finally beat the creature designated to be the target of my adventure... and it was the "opportunity" to start all over from the beginning. Bottom line - if you want to play a game like this play Diablo, or Titan Quest, or Path of Exile (which happens to be FREE!) -- those are ALL better games and finer examples of the genre. Barf. Oh, one last thing -- the difficulty scale on this game is literally offensive... it just multiplies (or divides, it would seem) monster hitpoints, and in the case of "Hero" difficulty (which I chose expecting a challenge, not a boring punishment) just makes monsters rapidly scale out of reach of being able to keep up with them. It won't make the monsters more challenging, but it WILL turn the entire game into button mashing the potion key while holding the attack button down. Also, most anti-climactic final battle ever -- it basically filled the screen with summons to the point the player cannot remain engaged to one target for more than an instant, making it literally impossible to swing more than three times at the same creature before dying. Luckily there is a (stupid) mechanic in the game that allows you to respawn exactly where you died at the loss of some xp and (mostly pointless) fame, so to beat the boss, (or anything for that matter) you merely need to swing twice before you die where you stand and keep coming back UNTIL you kill enough of the annoying summoners to face off with the boss, and if needed die numerous times to get him as well. Awful. Awful. Awful. If you played the game as a youngster and feel the need to retread this path somehow, be my guest. Those without the benefit of nostalgia have been warned.

17974790.review:
Isometric action-RPG dungeon crawler. A bridge between Diablo and Torchlight. Everything we have in the Torchlight we have because of this smooth project... And Fate itself is based mostly on the Diablo Hellfire best patterns.

If you're familiar with the Torchlight (and I guess you are), then you'll know everything the Fate got from the first sight.
Cartoon-styled graphics. Mild music, yet reminiscent to Matt Uelmen tracks. Very basic RPG elements but rich grinding system, making you constantly looking for more power-ups and new guns, which will be bigger and brighter... And many-many randomly generated levels (over 2 millions, and that's not a joke). Basically, you can keep playing in the Fate year by year and still be far from its depth (that's what Diablo 3 is only dreaming to be).

Comparing FATE to all other "Diablo killers" and especially Diablo 3 itself may not be the best idea, though. While generally all those games, would that be the Diablo itself, Titan quest, Sacred (etc.) - have some story on the plate, you can't say same thing about FATE. It is so random in every point, that even the main quest is not stable, and will be procedurally generated and different for any player. You'll not get any background there but only the very basic: you have a town with some folks, half of them will be traders or item randomizers, while other half will be sending you on some irrelevant quests. And all the quests in the game will be like "reach the level X and kill the monster Z" or "Bring me an item Y from level X".

Now, the main question: should you buy it? Yes.

Point one: it is good for any dungeon crawler fan. Hardly FATE can take your heart now, with all new titles like Van Helsing or Bastion (or dozens of others), but still it provides a very solid gameplay. A lot of challenge awaits!
Point two: even if you are not so deep in dungeon crawlers, but making numbers on Steam (would that be score of games in possession or achievement statistics, or both) - it is a good buy (especially with discount, of course). To make a gold on achievements, you'll probably need less than 5-6 hours.
Finally, this game has very high valued cards, so you have a good chance to buy the game and even make some money back on top of it!

Overall, it's not a hit or something you can't live without, but it's a very good pick. My mark 7.5/10

Truly a game of it's own design, this is actually one of the very first games I have ever played as a child. It is a deal of fun and can have it's ups and downs, but here is the overall run down of it. 

Pros - 
-Offline gameplay makes it perfect for those days without internet
-Storyline is compelling and easy enough to endure
-Side quests galore
-Minimal in questing so perfect for younger people or those with short attention spans
-No cursing or swearing, nor blood / gore
-Great beginner game
-Feels a lot like an early Skyrim with top down feels and hints of Dungeons and Dragons

Cons - 
-Questing is very direct
-After completing a generation, it becomes very repetitive
-Very repetitive gameplay through out
-Older game so graphics aren't as great as Fallout IV may be
-Lot's of grinding

This game really is to kill time, play during times of Internet crisis, or to have someone who may have never played too much video games before or may just be an adolescent as there isn't really anything bad on here. It is still fun and I am going to be picking up the next few expansions and trying them out.

17022734.review:
Played it's demo before in my childhood but didn't manage to finish it. Don't be fool by my game time i played it like for more than 12 hours and finished it. Fate is a simple and old game, it's a really fun dungeon crawler game.

The NPCs gives 1-3 level high quest depending on what dungeon level you are on, which is really convenient if you are heading to the main quest dungeon. The bad part about it is that once you've reach a dungeon level you can't get the quest in the dungeon you are in or any dungeon below your current dungeon you've explored, some quest have normal rewards but others have item rewards, but in this case you can manage the quest that you wanted to do even though it is limited.

The monsters in every level is different and they have different types of attacks, if you're making a summoner build you are going to die... a lot... so its best to cover up your character weaknesses.

One of the best part in this game is that you are able to turn your pet into a monster( not like slime, goblin or anything that has 2 hands and 2 legs) by feeding him fish, the fish you fed to your pet have a duration of how long your pet can be turned into a monster, you can turn your pet into a monster permanently if you want. And yes you can go fishing in the game in town or in the dungeon if you're lucky you can get rare items just by fishing.

Finally the skills in the game, there is no skill perk trees just old fashion Str, Dex, Vit and Int. But instead of a skill tree you can spend points on Weapon skills, Critical strike, Spell cast time, Attack spell level, Defence spell level and Charm spell level. You can use magic too, you can choose to buy them from a NPCs or explore the dungeon for it.

9/10 my childhood is complete

16786207.review:
With FATE now arriving to Steam, I figured I should share how great of a game it is! This is the precursor to Torchlight and Torchlight II. It's a very simple loot-fest with a never-ending and randomly-generated dungeon. It's an awesome game, it's easy to pick up and put down, doesn't require a lot of commitment or effort and it's very enjoyable. It now even has 1920x1080 resolution, which I'm pretty sure was a thing of the future when it was originally released. Some people are complaining about bugs with the Steam version, I've never had a problem with that one or the WildTangent download. This game is a classic, and it deserves no less than what I'm giving it. Amazingly fun and simple game, and very nostalgic to me and I'm sure a lot of other people that grew up with this game. It has tons of weapons, multiple skills to learn, and a great system to build your character towards a desired style. If you want to be a wizard, upgrade magic and the multiple magic skill perks. If you want to be a warrior, you can upgrade the type of weapon you want to use as well as your strength and dexterity. Tons of different ways to play it that will keep it interesting despite the very simplistic gameplay.

It has insane replay value as everything is randomized and there are hundreds of different ways to play through it. The main goal of the game is to traverse the dungeon doing tons of quests until you reach a certain level deep down which contains the main boss (it will take a long time to reach this level). Then you kill it and you're then allowed to retire (or continue down the dungeon for eternity if you so wish), which locks your current character, but passes down (and empowers) an heirloom of your choice. For example, if you get the best bow currently in the game, defeat the main boss with it and pass it down as you retire, you will be able to start a new character with this, now even MORE powerful bow. And so on...

Nothing not to love about this game, despite it's simplicity and lack of variety when looking at it materialistically, the game is just so damn fun to play I still play it to this day, along with it's other three successors: The Undiscovered Realm, The Traitor Soul, and The Cursed King, which by the way are all just as good! Get it now!

9.1/10

16322865.review:
（個人的に）名作と詠われている「Diablo」タイプ（というか「ハック&スラッシュ」タイプ）のRPGで全3部作（＋1作）あるシリーズ最初の作品。

なお、今作のキャラデーターは次回作にインポートする事が可能。

ゲームルールはペット（キャラメイク時に犬もしくは猫のいづれかを選ぶ。）と共にダンジョンの奥深く（大抵は40数階前後）に潜むボスモンスターを倒し、ダンジョンの入り口付近に居るローブをまとった老人（？）に話しかければゲームクリアというシンプルなもの。

2005年製というだけあって今となっては色々と少しきつい部分があるものの、後の「トーチライト」に受け継がれるペットシステムや一定時間ペットをモンスターに変身させて強化させる「魚」やレアアイテムを釣り上げられる「釣り」などがなかなか面白く、気が付いたら1週クリアまで嵌（は）まり込んでしまった。

また、「Diablo」のような職業の概念がなく、戦闘レベル（注1）が上がることでもらえるポイントで4つのステイタスを割り振ったり、戦闘レベルや名声レベル（注1）が上がるともらえるスキルポイントを振り分けることで自分の好きなタイプのキャラに出来るところや町の墓地に居る鍛冶屋？（注2）やダンジョン内にたまに置かれている魔法の金床（注2）で装備品にステイタスやスキルを上げる等の付加効果を付けられたり、装備品に付加効果を付けられる宝石を埋めこむ「ソケット」を増設できるのも個人的にGOOD。

ただ、最大の難点としてはロードがやたら長いことと、ラスボスクラスのモンスターを倒した後で老人に話しかけると引退（リタイヤ）するかどうか選べるのだが、そのとき「Yes」と選び、子孫となる新しいキャラを作ると今までプレイしたキャラでの冒険が一切出来ない上、次回作でのキャラインポートも出来ないのが個人的にマイナス。
（私の場合、万一に備え、クリア直前のセーブデーター（注3）のバックアップを取っていたので何とか助かったが、、）

また、難点かどうかは微妙だが一定階ダンジョンを下ると以前到達した階層のオートマッピングがクリア+その階居る敵がリスポーンすることがある事も付け加えておく。
（こちらに関してはうまく使えばもし出会った敵が強すぎたとき、以前の階層に戻ってリスポーンしたモンスターで経験稼ぎが出来るので、こういう措置は個人的にOKだと思う。）

ソレらの難点を差し引いてもハクスラ入門向けとしては個人的に良い感じのゲームなので興味があればどうぞ、、

Ps、バックアップしたセーブデーターを巻き戻すときはSteamクライアント左上の「Steam」>「設定」>「クラウド」内にある「Steamクラウドを有効化して、、、（以下略）」のチェックを外してクラウドを無効にしないとキャラデータがちゃんと巻き戻せないので注意。私もこのワナ（？）に軽くハマってしまった。）


注1、「戦闘レベル」は敵を倒すほか、町の人から依頼できるクエスト（主に特定のモンスター討伐や特定のアイテムを捜索するのがメイン。）をこなすと上がる「経験値」で上げることが出来、「名声レベル」はクエストをクリアするほか、ダンジョンにたまに現れる赤く光るモンスター（名前が紫色）を倒したり、「ヒーラー」（所謂宿屋のようなもの）のそばに居る人にお金を払うことで上げられる「名声値」で上げることが出来る。
なお、経験値は自分で敵を倒してもペットで敵を倒しても両方に経験値が入るのでご安心を、、

注2、金床は無料で利用できるが、鍛冶屋は有料（価格はアイテムの価値によって変化）で付加される能力はランダム。最悪の場合はペナルティーが付いたり、今まで掛けられた付加効果がすべてクリアされることも、、
なお、ダンジョンには金床の他にステイタスをランダムで上げ下げする机（の様なもの）やランダムで宝石や赤く光るモンスターが出てくる石像もあり。

注3、Win7の場合は「C:\ProgramData\WildTangent\FateSteam\Persistent\SAVE\」にある。

***FATE***
"You step into the portal..."
Getts and Bartleby are your best friends. Oh, and the healing woman too.
"Have I got a deal for you..."
'You caught a fish and found a *insert item that could certainly not fit into a fish here* in it!'
"Will you tempt Fate...?"
'You tempt fate... and nothing happens!'
Large chests are not large chests. They are 'Mimics' that have ridiculously sharp teeth and terrifying eyes.
You don't actually die when you die. So don't worry.

Honestly, most of the best memories I have were made by playing Fate. It is a super casual game, but I get really hardcore about it. From the joy of finding a legendary item, to the rush of enchanting it, to the depression induced by having all of the legendary enchantments taken away, to finding another legendary item from fishing, this game will always be one of my favourites. I have yet to find another voice actor that I enjoy more than Henry Dardenne, and the soundtrack is unreal. All-in-all, this game is worth your money and your time. I found myself accidentally playing until 4 in the morning the other day due to the "One More Level" effect FATE has. 1☺/1☺

This is a fun hacky-slashy dungeoneering game with the addition of a pet that can change shapes depending on what fish you feed it. You wouldnt think that was a game-making mechanic but I'm finding myself keeping my favorite fish on hand, spending a lot of time thinking about what eventual permanent change I'd like for him to undergo.

The randomly generated dungeons keep from being repetitive by a very small view area and a lot of challenges - you think you're awesome mchero-sauce until you step too far into a big room and pull so many mobs that you run screaming into the darkness like a little pansy. 

The quests are a little annoying in that you have to pay attention to what level they're sending you to. You can only "carry" three quests in a go, so dont clutter up your journal with the one that will make you wait for three whole levels.

It's a great little time killer. No story, no maps, no mess.

16011318.review:
I'd been wanting to play this game for many years after first hearing about it back when it was new -- a Diablo clone during the action-rpg drought of much of the 2000s, with all these nice features like a permanent pet that can hold and sell your junk for you while you adventure?  Sounded awesome.

Of course, much time passed and I ended up playing Torchlight and its sequel before this game.  And on that note, I can go ahead and give you the meat of the review:

[b]Torchlight is, simply put, a better version of this game.[/b]

And yes, I know it's by the same guys and came before Torchlight -- but there's really no reason to play this instead; there's absolutely nothing that this game does better, or even as well, and they're quite succinctly the exact same game only with Torchlight being newer and more improved.  It's not like how they're both direct clones of Diablo 1 but that game has a unique atmosphere and gamefeel that makes it still very much worth playing separately; no, these games are *the exact same thing*, except Torchlight is better.

Torchlight has classes; Fate does not.  Fate makes you play a generic character whose un-alterable starting stats are those of a warrior class, even though, for example, playing as a mage is very powerful.  Likewise, Torchlight has an actual skill tree system a la Diablo 2 whereas Fate has a flat page of skills of which no playstyle will ever need to put points into more than 3 or 4 max.

Torchlight has a variety of visually luscious dungeon areas, a unique backdrop to each set of floors, whereas Fate hits you with a generic and unappealing handful of locales randomly chosen floor-by-floor.  Torchlight also offers enemies cohesive to the area at which you fight them to some degree whereas Fate throws a random mishmash of almost every enemy in the game in your direction each floor, with lower floors having you see a bit more larger stuff along with 'elite' and 'legendary' versions of the smaller stuff to make their HP pools monsterous; there is no rhyme or reason.

Torchlight has a massive amount of powerful equipment to find and collect, offering you many build options and ways to increase your power, while Fate quickly makes you realize a simple and painful truth; farm the shops until you have the maximum gem slots possible in every piece of equipment, then farm the mage shop until you have the required amount of superior gems, asap.  There's your endgame equipment; if you're lucky enough to find higher-tier stuff later with the required sockets then good for you, but don't hold your breath.  And this goes for all playstyles.

Torchlight has a defined endgame, final floor and final boss, and then a separate 'infinite' dungeon to test your skills if you want to keep playing.  Fate gives you a randomized boss monster on a random floor and then gives you the option to go deeper in the same dungeon for no real reason.  I will say that the 'descendant' system is interesting, but is it really worth it?  Oh sure, you can become insanely powerful and tear up the dungeons for hundreds of levels if you really want, but you've seen all the game has to offer by floor 20 or so max, and by the time you get to your final boss situated 2 or 3 times deeper than that you'll be well and truly done with the game.  Even the powerful endgame unique equipment that serves as the carrot-on-a-stick for many action-RPG players is a joke, here -- as far as I can tell, you can get *all* uniques even extremely early in the game via fishing holes, and though some seems tantalizing at first you quickly realize their benefits are still not comparable to a socketed, plain version of the same item; and while a socketed unique may be the ideal, good luck with that.  You'll never find them socketed already, and if you dare spend millions of gold at the enchanter in the tiny off-chance you'll get one added (when ideally you'd want 2 or more), you're liable to revert the item to a powerless piece of scrap.

So all in all?  Yeah, no.  Skip it.  Play Diablo, Diablo 2, Diablo 3 (yes, Diablo 3), Titan Quest, Grim Dawn, Path of Exile, the Van Helsing games, and any other action-RPG before you think about this one.  And especially Torchlight.  Because it's literally the exact same game but better in every conceivable way.

That being said, I am still going to check out the other Fate games and see if they're... fated... for better reviews.  Heh.  Haha... *cough*

15992829.review:
FATE is really good, particularly for a decade-old game. The graphics are simple, but cute and colorful. The music's cheerful. And the gameplay is a simple concept that really keeps you engaged. In my case, this definitely isn't nostalgia speaking, and I'm not looking at it through the rose-colored lenses of my childhood. I never played it, or any others in the series, until recently. And it's kind of impressive just how well this game has held up over time.

The game's premise, borrowed liberally from the original Diablo, is a basic dungeon-crawler RPG. Each level of the dungeon is randomly generated and filled with items and monsters. Villagers in town will give you quests tied to specific levels, and you journey in and out of the dungeon as you complete your tasks. You can only take three quests at a time, and it's up to you whether you take the maximum on every level and explore every corridor, or rush through on your way to the final boss. 

As you complete quests and hack and slash your way through the dungeon's monsters, you gain experience, and leveling up allows you to increase your skills and stats in specific areas.  Looting dungeons gives you gold and items, and there are also several vendors in town who can sell you items, or perform various services. You can also earn money (and find rare items) by catching fish in the fishing holes found throughout the game.

Got too much stuff to carry around in the dungeon? No problem. You'll have a pet, an un-killable companion that can also ferry your junk to town in exchange for gold. Your pet can also help fight enemies, but it will flee if its health gets too low and be no use in the fight. If the basic cat or dog isn't powerful enough, you can feed your pet fish in order to transform them into different monsters found in the game. If this sounds an awful lot like Torchlight, it's pretty evident that FATE was a huge influence on that game.

There is a main story quest that is basically just a harder boss on some random level close to lvl 50. Since the levels are generated randomly, you could just keep playing by continuing down for thousands of levels. Even without the practically unending dungeon, randomly generated levels and a pretty big combination of skills and gear gives FATE almost infinite replayability. This is actually featured in the game well, since finishing the main quest allows you to create a "descendant" character. This new character can keep one "heirloom" item but begin his or her own adventure. It's especially cool that you can also import characters from FATE into the sequels as well, heirlooms and all.

As an RPG, FATE is not terribly deep. But it is a lot of fun, and it's a great – if somewhat casual – way to blow off steam while crawling through maze-like dungeons and blasting or slashing your way through colorful mobs of creatures.

This is one of those games that makes you wish Steam had three buttons for recommendation yes, no and 'neutral'.  Fate is your atypical dungeon crawler.  You get quests from the villagers that correspond to the dungeon lvl you are on with either a) kill boss X or b) gain item Y requests, with the vague goal of reaching lvl 50 and killing the main boss.

15880615.review:
Do you like copious amounts of dungeon crawling that never ends? Then Fate might be for you. I've clocked in over 50 hours on this game this past year and I really had no idea what the end game goal was. I got it into my head at some point that it would all be over at Level 100. There'd be this grand baddie that I'd face off with my minions in an epic battle and I'd prove victorious. When that never happened and I was at Level 103 I became suspicious. Turns out I just had to go to floor 51. I over shot my goal by 52 floors. 

That proves 2 things. One, I clearly wasn't informed of where I had to go and two, the game doesn't do a good job of informing you of your goal except at the very beginning. I would have never guessed that the old wizard at the entrance was who you needed to talk to to get your end goal. Unlike all the other town folk who have a big exclamation mark above their heads when they have quests for you the guy with the end quest was just chilling at the entrance so I never spoke to him every time I went to town. That's just poor informing on the game's part. Not to say that I didn't thoroughly enjoy this game and if I wasn't trying to complete the achievements, one of which I didn't get until I was somewhere around Level 100 I probably wouldn't have played for so long. 

This game is a grind but there's lots of loot and villagers supply you with endless quests for you to keep going and going and going. Weapons and armor are plentiful but I found item enhancements to help more than picking the weapon with the highest attack power. My favorite armor was one with a defense rating of 42 but it had a bunch of buffs that increased my damage by 40% and my dexterity by 70%. It also helped that it absorbed 9% of damage dealt. You'll also find out pretty quick that your starting animal is useless. Find fish to transform it as much as you can until you get one that you can live with. I particularly liked the Ebony Stalker. Summon spells are also your friend. I can't count how many times I was killed in seconds by mobs of enemies. So get yourself a Venomous Wyvern summon and always have 6 around you. They don't do much damage but they sure do come in handy when you want enemies to target something that isn't you.

This is Duracell bunny of dungeon crawlers. That being said if you like Fate you'd love Torchlight. It's just like Fate only better and it has an actual story as a plausible reason for your dungeon crawling that comes to a clearly defined end.

15833007.review:
The sad truth is, Torchlight has obsoleted this game.  It shouldn't come as a surprise.  The same lead developer, made several years later.  Torchlight expands upon many of the elements started in this game, and fixes a lot of the problems this game has.  Torchlight itself is not a perfect game, it does improve upon this one in nearly every aspect.

Even ignoring the fact that a superior version of this game exists, this game is just not that fun.  It's very slow, particularly for an aRPG.  It relies on an old, clunky interface and mechanics (such as limits town portal and identify scrolls, etc.)  Yea, they were staples of the time, but we've moved beyond them.  And this review is taking place now, with the games and mechanics that exist today.

I love old games.  Even ones that didn't age well.  But the ones I play generally make me want to KEEP playing them.  This game does not.  And in the end, that's what a recommendation comes down to.  So, no, I cannot recommend this game.

15537870.review:
Fate - это игра в жанре Hack'n Slash.
Вы стартуете в городе, позже входите в замок-темницу, и опускаетесь всё ниже и ниже.
Вы будете уничтожать разных монстров, среди которых есть полу-боссы. Будете получать оружие и броню, которую потом можно будет продать в городе.
В игре есть два типа опыта - обычный, который вы получаете за убийство монстров, после достижения определённого
количества вам дают новый уровень, можно улучшить характеристики (5 баллов), а также 2 балла особых умений скиллов (лучшее владение определённым оружием, лучший критический удар, возможность блока, магические умения); второй тип опыта - известность, вы можете получить известность за выполнение заданий, или просто купить её у менестреля за деньги (каждый уровень известности даёт 4 балла скиллов).
В городе же можно сделать следующее: взять до 3-х квестов от жителей одновременно - квесты бывают на получение определённого предмета, убийства некоторого количества обычных монстров или убийство полу-босса, за выполненное задание вам дадут опыт, очки известности и золото (но если вам понравится какой-то из квестовых предметов, вы вправе отменить квест, и забрать вещь себе); также в городе можно бесплатно вылечиться (в том числе и от заражения ядом), есть разные торговцы, в том числе эликсирами, бронёй и оружием, а также магическими предметами; в городе можно зачаровать своё оружие и броню, чем больше зачарований, тем дороже это будет.
В вашем квесте вам будет помогать ваше животное (в начале собака или кот), оно будет нападать на врагов, получать новые уровни, а также нести ваши вещи, и его можно будет отправить в город продать предметы. Если жизни животного  приблизятся к нулю, животное просто будет беспорядочно бегать, пока вы его не вылечите, умереть оно не может. Если вы сами умрёте - вам будет предложено оставить всё золото на месте смерти, и перенестить на 3 уровня назад, либо заплатить 1/10 от ваших денег и перенестись в начало уровня, либо потерять часть опыта и вернуться на место смерти. Также в игре можно ловить рыбу удочкой, рыба будет превращать ваше животное в других монстров, более мощных (рыбу также можно покупать у торговцев).
У этой игры нет конца, она бесконечная, в ней будут бесконечные уровни подземелий, и бесконечная прокачка (в том числе и предметов). Её можно сравнить с играми Diablo 1-2, а также Torchlight 1, игру делали те же разработчики,
и многое взяли из серии Диабло, а позже остальное воплотили в серии Торчлайт.
Официальный конец игры - убить главного босса на 49-м уровне, но можно играть и после этого. У игры просто аркадный непритязательный геймплей, он хорошо затягивает, в игре достаточно различных монстров, магических предметов и умений. Все квесты выдаются рандомно. После прохождения последнего босса есть возможность отправить вашего персонажа на пенсию, и играть за его потомка (за бывшего персонажа играть уже нельзя будет), потомок получает часть умений предыдущего персонажа.
У игры есть 4 уровня сложности, и на лёгком она проходится очень хорошо. У этой игры есть несколько продолжений, добавляющий новых монстров и заклинания. Я рекомендую эту игру, с удовольствием её прошёл. Рекомендую любителям серий Diablo и Torchlight, любителям слэшеров и просто хороших игр.

15040750.review:
10/10 Best time sink simulator for the price.

Let me preface this by saying that I have put almost three full days of playtime into this game at time of writing, so I obviously like it.

Fate is a Dungeon Crawler that came out in 2005, while the music is somewhat similar to that of Diablo, it does fit the setting and does aid with immersion quite well. The graphic are great for 2005 and can hold their own in a modern gaming market given recent events. (I am looking at you, AC Unity.)

A very basic gist of the story is this: big bad monster in big bad dungeon. Adventurous hero of unknown origin and unremarkable (non-existant?) achievement must go and slay this baddie as s/he is clearly our last and greatest hope. So off you go with little more than a pointy stick and your trusty pet compainion to try and stomp a monster's teeth in.

Every floor of the dungeon is random, in the sense that is a series of rooms with sporadic and often unyeildy connecting paths. As a whole, the entire dungeon has a nice and bumpy difficulty curve that, if you are strategic and don't mind some grinding, you can completely kick the piss out of.

I think one of the drawbacks of this game is one key game mechanic in particular. I won't be disclosing which mechanic this is, as once you figure out why it is useful, you are going to abuse this machanic like you just found out the button combination to get free soda in the soda machine at the office. Once that happens, the game loses quite a bit of difficulty. One of many things that really makes up for this is another mechanic, Enchanting, which is really more of a gamble than the actual "gambling" mechanic. 

Another thing I really like about this game are the items obtainable and the playstyles available, FATE wholeheartedly supports the idea of having your cake and eating it too, though various stat selections on leveling up, you can do just about anything, or do everything if you really want to. This is great for me, because I am the type of person that if I get a massive 'fuck you' sword, I want a second 'fuck you' sword or a superpowered sheild of 'I don't give a fuck'. And the game lets you do that! And I love that about it.

All in all, it is a great game if you are looking for something to introduce you to Dungeon Crawling, or if you are looking for something to eat up free time cheaply.
