14216963.review:
Fate is pretty decent.  It's an RPG that could be considered the father of Torchlight.  Made a few years earlier, it incorporates a number of things that Torchlight did, particularly the use of the pet as both a beast of burdon and as an ally which is transformable by fish.  It has randomly generated dungeons, which is always nice, and has been produced well.  

That said, I am finding it a bit boring.  As a fighter specialising in swords, I've found most of the drops to be magic-geared, or aimed at axe-wielders.  I'd say about 95% of the drops are of no interest to me at all, and this tends to make hacking your way through the levels a bit monotonous.

I'm also finding it annoying that it is all too easy to die in the game, especially if you're focusing on what's happening on-screen.  The warning that health is low seems to come too late, so you end up having to divide your attention between the fighting and supervising the health bar.  The pet also seems to spend about 50% of its time fleeing.

My last moan is that the resolution doesn't seem adjustable, and I'm finding that I'd like to be able to zoom out a little more and with more detail - many of the characters seem rather large and chunky, as though this game was aimed at kids.

All said though, the game is cheap enough, and I bought my copy during a sale.  If you like RPGs, give it a go.

13619925.review:
シンプルなハクスラ。
ストーリーは冒頭で語られる程度で、ランダムダンジョンの奥深くにいるボスを倒すのが目的となっている。サブクエストをこなしつつ、ダンジョンの奥深くを目指し、アイテムを集めキャラを強化していくという純粋なダンジョンクロールハクスラの要素は抑えてあって面白い。

ユニークな特徴としては、スタミナがあり走ることができるという点があるが、常時走るが必須でありスタミナ切れたらポーションで回復するという面倒臭さが感じられるだけで上手く活かされていない印象だ。また、もう1つの特徴としてはクラスが分けられておらずスキル制ということが挙げられ、自分の好みの武器や魔法のスキルを上げることで、キャラ育成に個性を付けることができる。スキル固有のスペシャル攻撃のようなものは無いが、その代わりとして魔法を上手く使っていくことが重要となってくる。実際に魔法は効果的なものが多い。

戦闘については、チャンピオン相当するモンスターが多くの魔法を使い分けてくるので強い。回復、召喚、バフ･デバフ、攻撃魔法を使ってくるような敵が登場することも。

ストーリーについてはほぼ皆無で、ラスボスさえも恐らくランダムキャラタイプかつ地下40階以下の階層でランダムで出現するようになっていると思われる。ラスボス撃破後は、引退するかどうかを選択でき、引退する場合にはアイテムを1つ引き継いで新キャラで再スタートとなる。引退しない場合は引き続き、同じキャラでダンジョンを延々と潜っていくということになる。

装備については、ジェムとエンチャントで強化することができる。エンチャントはデメリット特性が付くことがあるが金の続く限り強化していけるので、金さえあれば割とどうにでもなってしまう印象だ。ただし最悪の場合、エンチャント失敗で特性が全消滅する可能性があるので注意。また、釣りで結構な確率でLegendary装備を手に入れることができる。むしろ敵を倒してトレハンするよりも釣りの方が実入りが良いと思われるくらいだ。

死亡時の復活条件選択、ペットや釣りや引退システムがあり、どうしてもTorchlightを意識してしまうが、これはTorchlightの開発者にFATEの元開発者がいるためで、ある意味Torchlightの原型とも言えなくも無い。古いゲームであるために洗練されていないUIの不親切さが感じられるが、それが些細なことのように感じさせてくれるシンプルな面白さがある。Torchlight(2より1)を好む人には楽しめると思う。

12657769.review:
Fate is a classic dungeon-crawler that was at one point almost the best RPG of the year (this opinion varies per big game-review company), the Combat is rather simple, all is easy to understand, but that doesn't stop a wild hoard of giant lava-worms from killing you.      This 'is' an early entry to the top-down dungeon-crawling RPG genre, so it can be pretty easy to come up with a strategy that makes you near invincible (still takes a bit of time to finish said strategy); the graphics are actually quite nice for 2005, and it supports Anti-Aliasing (probably like 2X MSAA at most, tho).
I'd highly recommend this if: You're looking for a dungeon-crawler you can pick up and leave without feeling like you didn't make progress.

12485326.review:
FATE is A RPG dungeon crawler brought to you by the people at Wild Tanget. This game is A classic. Only thing that would make me love this game anymore is if it had multiplayer. The game centers around YOU be you Dicky Gobblkoque or John Doe. And unlike some games, this game only has ONE dungeon. With an infineite amount of levels of which new monsters come and they also increase in levels. These monsters change in variety from a basic slime to yetis. This game, although stable can have bugs every once in a while. One of which i had where my normal cursor stayed on the screen when i started the game. Not allowing me to click any options and FATE took over my computer. Forcing me to cold reboot. But once you are in the actual game, I doubt you will find any glitches. Like i said eariler the monsters level up the deeper into the dungeon you go. So playing on the harder difficulty like I do you can sometimes rush into A level you just can't handle. The spells in this game are extremely varied, sometime even pretty unique. From making monster your friends to attack other enemies, to poisonous clouds that drain the life from your (Not undead) Enemies. There is also a stamina system in the game. Because even heros get tired. This really is only to slow you down. Making it so you can't run forever so thats pretty bad. And one of the best parts... FISHING. Yes, the developers decided fishing would make a great part of their game. Fish can be used to turn your pet into magical ceatures. And fishing can also get some of the rarer items in the game. The quest system is your standard. "Go kill this for me/get this for me and ill give you gold EXP and sometimes an item" its not much to talk about but its worth a mention. And mage is the only extremly remarkable class, albiet the hardest one to really lift off on. 

So all in all, fate is a pretty good game. If you like dungeon crawlers then you will love this game without a doubt, if your not a fan of dungeon crawlers i still recommend it. You might just find an exception to your distaste.

8/10

12196821.review:
(IMPORTANT INFORMATION BELOW REVIEW)
Used to play this all the time. Lost the CD, found it again on Steam, and had a blast.
What you've got here is a decent Diablo clone with a ridiculous amount of depth. There's lots of customization in the way of attributes, skills, equipment, a pet, and magic, and the game constantly rewards your efforts by allowing you to improve more and more in each of these departments. It can get quite difficult and hectic at times (seriously, why must I fight more than 10 enemies at once), so if you don't like the idea of teleporting back to the town every five minutes, micromanaging your armor based on stat bonuses, or bringing up your inventory a million times in one battle, this probably isn't for you. If you can deal with all that, then get it, install it, and ready yourself for one awesome, yet often overlooked, game.

-----

Now then, be warned, this game has its share of problems. I ran into a few in-game bugs, but none of them really broke the game or made it easier or harder. More important than that, there is a serious issue of some Steam users not being able to run the game, and while WildTangent (the devs) have made an effort to address this problem, there is still a relevant portion of people who have bought the game and just had it sitting in their library since. It isn't always necessarily the same thing giving everyone this problem as well, so what works as a solution for one person may not work for you. I got it working after a few months, but if you want to play it and have any doubts about whether you can run it, you probably want to read the forums and see what people, for their specific cases, have done in the way of trying to fix the problem.

12124291.review:
I received FATE through a bundle that contained other games I was interested in getting, so I did not actively seek it out. However, I'm a huge fan of some RPGs, so I figured I would try out FATE. After all, I was obsessed with WildTangent back in the day. (Still hoping for a Steam version of Blackhawk Striker 2!)

Sadly, FATE turned into a game that I do not wish to play. However, I would still recommend it, which is why I'm giving it a positive review.

The best way for me to describe FATE is that it's a never-ending dungeon. Whereas other RPGs will have you encounter multiple dungeons alongside the main story or as side quests, FATE is simply one gigantic dungeon. There is little story here; it's all about becoming the most famous adventurer to conquer what lies beyond the Gate next to the town of Grove. There are quests that the villagers of Grove will give you, but they're simply "Get back in that dungeon, to a specific level, and beat up this specific monster there. Get the item he drops and come back." This furthers your progress with experience, gold, and fame. Way more focus on gameplay (see below) than story.

The aesthetics are not Battlefield 4, but they completely match with the time period the game was developed in as well as in the style of RPG the game was going for. It's very much old-timey. However, don't let the graphics mislead you into thinking that this is one of the really difficult RPGs of old; it's actually quite easy to pick up and play when you get through the opening loading screens. I would have liked a tutorial or quick "here's what you're doing and how you do it" conversation with a tutorial NPC or something, but it's fine as it is. Level 1 of the dungeon is straightforward and pretty much sets the bar for what players should expect.

Of note, however, is that there's a difficulty setting. I set it to Page, the easiest. So it might just be me. The hardest difficulty, Legend, might be what the veterans from old RPGs would like to start out at to really get a challenge. :P

Gameplay is interesting, to say the least. Battles and encounters are real-time, so you have to stay on your toes and watch where you're going. Thankfully, it's easy to discern an enemy approaching you, so you have time to react. But enemies do have various speeds, both for "walking" and for attacking. I highly appreciate that an enemy's important statistics are mentioned just by hovering over it; it's very easy to tell what it's weak or strong to.

The music and other sound effects are top-notch, and I'm definitely going to research into the FATE soundtrack after posting this review. Very enjoyable, even to just sit in town or the main menu and listen for a while.

tl;dr FATE is simply one giant dungeon, but it does it pretty well. This is not my kind of game, and I didn't enjoy it as much as other people would, but I would definitely recommend it because, for the kind of RPG it is, I think it's worth a look for all RPG fans.

11915705.review:
シンプルなディアブロ系ゲーム。俯瞰視点とクリックでキャラを操作し、敵を倒して経験値とアイテムを入手して行く古典的ゲームシステム。これと言って目新しいシステムなども無く、元になったディアブロ2辺りと比べても更に単純な程ではあるが、丁寧に作られて居るので意外と面白い。
ひたすらトレハンをしたい、敵を倒してキャラ強化したい的な需要は十分満たせるクオリティはあると思う。

実はこのゲーム、最初に純粋な近接キャラでゲームを始めて見た所、ただ敵をクリックして攻撃する事しか出来ず、単純すぎてつまらないゲームだとレビューに書いて終わりにする所だった。実際、純粋な近接キャラで育てると魔法などが使えず、技なども無い為、元となったディアブロ2よりも単純なゲームになってしまい、面白いとは言いがたい。
このゲームでは魔法を選択して的確に使用していく、と言う部分以外ではプレイヤーが介入する余地が殆ど無いので、ある程度魔法前提でキャラクターを作っていかなければ、ゲームプレイが味気ない物になってしまう様だ。

二人目のキャラでは魔法特化と難易度最高を選んでみた所、歯応えのある操作の忙しさと、緊張感のあるバランスが得られた。ただし、このゲームは基本的に難易度は低いので、ディアブロ系ゲームに慣れていると最高難易度でも簡単過ぎてつまらないかもしれない。
また、魔法特化キャラの場合アイテムドロップが異常に偏っているので、トレハン要素がほぼ無くなってしまうのは残念だった。このゲームは何故かダンジョンでドロップするアイテムはほぼ全て武器アイテムとなっており、魔法使い系で使えるアイテムは手に入らないと言って良い。その為魔法使い系では、トレハンはあくまで高額で売れるアイテムを探す程度の意味しか無い。

流石に三人目を作る事まではしてないが、以上の事を踏まえるとある程度武器装備が可能なキャラに自己強化や敵弱体化魔法などを覚えさせながらプレイするのが、このゲームでアクション性とトレハン要素を維持する最適なキャラ設計かなと思う。

とりあえずのエンディングまでクリアーするのに20時間弱程度。直接的な二周目などは無いが、クリアーしたキャラからアイテムなど引き継いだキャラクターで二周目プレイは可能。
この種のゲームとしてはプレイ時間が長い方と言う事もないが、内容はほぼ純粋にダンジョンに潜り続ける事になるので、これで十分と言った感もある。
ボスキャラなどが存在せず、淡々と敵を倒してダンジョンの階層を進んで行くだけなので単調さも否定できない。
ゲームとしての作りは丁寧なので「ディアブロクローンであってそれ以上でもそれ以下でも無い」事を踏まえてプレイすれば、それなりに楽しめると思う。

[h1]FATE, you were my childhood![/h1]

FATE is a simply dungeon crawler - like Torchlight or Diablo - but less story (which isn't a problem). You have the task to create a character, choose your pet and go deeper and deeper into the dungeon.

++ It is an old RPG, but better than some today!
++ addictive
++ can be played for hours and hours (explore different levels or just go fishing)
++ you can go fishing!
+ lots of little tasks, but everytime the same (kill that, find that, bring me that, etc.)
+ loads of weapons, armor and spells!
+ the monsters get bigger and stronger with every level/dungeon
+ typical skilltree (strength, vitality, dexterity, magic)
+ money is not really necessary
+ easy achievements (except "Fate Ensured" - beat the endboss)

[i]Also FATE is not that perfect![/i]

- it's often the same...so I rushed the last 10 levels
- play it on hard, the remaining is too easy
- I don't like the sounds of the pets (they're too annoying)
- the controls were a little bit tricky (in my opinion)
- If you are fast, you are done with in 10 hours - but you can play further
- Ok ok ok. This game is from 2005, so don't expect the next "Crysis".
- the endboss is not everytime the same...it's a minus point, because I had a [b]fckng bug[/b] - there are also dragons, but NO - it has to be a bug.


You've reminded me of my childhood - FATE - and thanks for that.
Buy it if you want to play an nice and old RPG!

It's a FATE!": [b]8,5/10[/b]

11265897.review:
Did I buy Torchlight again ?   

------
Edit:  I know Torchligh came after.  I bought it first.   My point is about gaming experience and uniqueness of experience.  It's not like you're waiting for the next one to be released.  You can choose to spend on Fate, Fate Undiscovered realms, Torchlight I or Torchlight II.  

Torchlight II has added game experience which makes it best.   The other three are almost identical, so if I'm going to choose one of them, it'll be Torchlight I because it has better achievements.   

-----

I bought this recently.  I had never played it previously.    I have played both Torchlight games.   This game and the first Torchlight could be clones of one another.   I honestly can't think of one thing that differs.   

Get five attribute points to distribute per level up - check.  Get a skill point to apply to warrior skill, mage skill or ranged weapon skill - check.   Have a pet - check.  Can transform pet - check.  Use fish to transform pet - check.  
Use portal scroll to navigate to most recent level and go down a level - check.   Gamble - check.

Pros:
+ Classic, fun dungeon-crawling gameplay.
+ Countless hours of gameplay.
+ A hefty amount of replay value.

Mehs (possible cons and possible pros):
== It's pretty much a relic of a game. The graphics, animations, etc. fit with its original release date.
== The dungeon crawler experience in general can get a bit repetitive after so many hours. It doesn't vary a whole lot.
== It lacks any sort of co-op gameplay. I personally believe that would've been a fun addition to the Steam version of the game.
== They removed cheat codes from the game. You can still edit data files to cheat, however. Look it up if you're interested.
== You need a lot of spare time on your hands to actually beat the game. When I say a lot, I mean a sh*t load.

Cons:
- Distasteful use of a semi-permadeath mechanic. Dying can really break you in differentiating ways, such as losing all of your gold, your experience, your place in the dungeon, or your fame. Considering how frequently you can die on even normal mode, you may end up just dropping the game.

9976845.review:
Decent graphics for a game its age, and quite a lot of bang for your buck given its relatively low price tag. That said, the story is essentially non-existent and the gameplay is pretty shallow - you basically just run through randomly-generated dungeons killing hordes of monsters while completing meaningless quests. Gameplay follows a pretty simple formula:
- Go to town. Buy gear. Get quests.
- Go to dungeon. Kill monsters. Find loot. Complete quests.
- Go back to town. Sell loot. Get quest rewards.
And then you more or less just repeat until you get bored. It's pretty standard dungeon-crawler faire.
Now, if you really like generic dungeon crawlers and are a big fan of the action/RPG genre, you'll probably have fun with this game, though you might be better off going with something like Titan Quest if you want a bit more depth.
In sum, FATE is a good game to pick up if you're just looking for a simple dungeon-crawler to play. It won't be the greatest game you play all year, but it won't be the worst either. All things considered, it's worth the $7.99 price tag.

9863909.review:
A dungeon delver with... tons of armor and weapons, gems you can socket to extra damage or defense, orcs in town that can retrieve the gems or remove the gems in your favorite weapon or armor, your choice of a cat or dog pet, fishing that will transform your pet into lots of tougher creatures, leveling up that allows you to customize your character's strength, dexterity, magic, and vitality to create the character that you want whether it's a warrior, mage, archer, tank, or dual-wielding rogue, and even a shady character in a side alley that will let you gamble for elite gear.

Sound familiar?  It should because this was the game that preceeded Torchlight and Torchlight 2.

Developed by Travis Baldree, who recently left Runic Games to start his own project, FATE seems simple enough to play, especially for action RPG fans who have Torchlight in their library.  Delve deeper and you soon find you will need to think about your choices.  Strength isn't just the catch-all for warriors, you'll need to add points to dexterity or you'll miss all of your swings.  Dexterity isn't the catch-all for rogues because the quests put you up against tough boss monsters who will likely kill you if you don't beef up your other stats.

An interesting twist not present in the Torchlight games is the concept of fate.  When you get quests, you are told what piece of gear you will need to retrieve from the dungeon and what you'll receive in return.  Once you get the gear, you can choose to keep it or turn in the quest for your reward.  The problem is you know the stats of the gear in your hand but you won't know whether the reward has better stats unless you turn the quest in.  It's a little bit of a Monty Hall problem.  In addition, turning in quests give you fame and as you gain recognition, you will receive 'fate points' that allow you to specialize in specific skills.  These are very specific right down to the type of weapon (hammer, axe, sword, etc...) or the type of magic (attack, defense, charm) you are using.  So do you keep the gear and miss out on your fame or do you go for door number two?

You may have had the chance to experience a trial version the game many years ago if you happened to get a HP computer.  It works just fine on my Windows 7 x64 system, and you no longer have to deal with Wildtangent's scammy client that tried to make you pay by the hour.  I also like the variation and weapons and armor.  Like Torchlight, you get so see your new gear close up as you leave.  

It's as fun to play now as it was back then.  Buy it!

8993111.review:
This is a large chunk of my PC gaming childhood right here, and I was so surprised and thrilled to see it had come to Steam (yay). And yay, they added achievements and yay, trading cards too! That right there is a triple yay.

Before Travis Baldree whooped Diablo's ass with Torchlight, he whooped Diablo's ass with Fate. No, really. If you like either of those games, Fate certainly deserves your attention. It has a certain innocent charm to it that fills me with a childish sense of wonder and curiosity. It makes me feel... at peace. Good. It's just fun, with a particular allure to it underneath the perhaps somewhat generic presentation.

Unfortunately, it seems to me that this game is really overlooked; a hidden gem that no one has attached to their socket. I have never met anyone who's familiar with this game, and that makes me sad. So here I am spreading the word. Play Fate, now. It is... your fate. But you'll like it! In my case, I love it, and I hope that, now that it's on Steam, many other people can experience the happiness Fate brings to my heart. I'm probably being too nostaglic about this game, but I just really, really enjoyed Fate back in the day and I'm enjoying it all over again now.

8777771.review:
FATE is the spiritual predecessor of Torchlight, and it shows.  Mechanics like "pets carrying loot to town" were developed right here.  The graphical style is similar, the play style is familiar, and the entire game revolves around procedurally generated quests and dungeons.  If these are the elements of an Action RPG that you enjoy, then do pick up this game and play a little slice of history.  If, however,  you want a thoroughly modern and highly polished experience, then stick with Torchlight 2 or Path of Exile instead.

That all said, it has been my experience that most fans of ARPGs have a little bit of retro-gamer in them.  If this describes you, then stop reading this right now and start playing FATE.  It will give that pin-prick of retro style in a package that is just as fun as other ARPGs.

The only detractors for me are the lack of any sort of skill tree system, or anything else that truly differentiates one play style from another.  While it is true that FATE's character progression is intendedly more organic than a class-based game like Diablo 2 (and succeeds, as far as it goes), it comes off as retrograde as compared to character progression in a more modern game like Torchlight 2 or even Diablo 3.

Bottom line: If you enjoy Action RPGs, then pick this up on sale.  You won't be disappointed.

8741785.review:
Fate is a nice game and all, and like many of the players here I have fond memories of playing it way back when, but it's hard to recommend it at full price to players new to game.

The gameplay is pretty standard; left click to attack, right click to cast, you have health and mana, none of the spells will surprise you, and while there are quite a few different monsters, none of them really differ from each other. 

The "plot" is to kill a randomly generated monster on a random level with a lot of randomly generated side quests thrown in which [i]sounds[/i] nice, but soon things will start repeating and it will begin feel more like a never-ending grind with no real goal.

I'm not say it's a bad game, but for a bit more you'd be better off with its sucessor, Torchlight, which has pretty much the same mechanics but a better plot, a more refined feel and more variation in its monsters and items beyond slightly different stats.

8569513.review:
I am glad Fate came to steam. I played this game long ago when it first came out, it was nice to revisit the game now as an adult.  
 
Overall, the game is decent. Granted its not anything amazing when compared to its predecessors... but back in the day it was quite something. The fun in this game comes from the complete randomness and endless play killing waves of monsters while progressing deeper and trying to get the best set of gear you can. 
 
It does have its flaws. Item skill point requirements are not well balanced and can make gearing up early in the game quite difficult. Fishing is almost required to get well geared, and the fishing mechanic is a bit buggy causing you to fail the catch even if you clicked in time to catch it. Perhaps the worst feature however is the chance to completely loose all enchantment on your gear when enchanting, I would not advise enchanting anything that you wouldn't want to lose... because you very well might.  
 
I would recommend the game to anyone, it is good for at least 2 playthroughs. I'm not sure its worth the $8 price tag, i picked it up on a sale for much cheaper.

8564883.review:
I remember playing FATE for the first time many years ago. It is one of my favorite games. Graphics don't even begin to compare to today's new games, but the game is so much fun that it doesn't even matter. I can spend hours scaling the dungeons. It never gets old. I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for hours of fun at a good price. 

In the Steam version, the cheat console is missing, probably because the game includes achievements and the cheats would make getting all the achievements way too easy. This can cause a problem if one specific bug is encountered... I haven't seen it yet in this version, but in the past, when I played FATE, I remember getting caught in between two objects in such a way that there's no way to move. When closing this game, it saves EVERYTHING, including your EXACT position. That means if you encounter this bug and then try to close the game, your character is forever locked in a place where he/she will never be able to move from again. With the "cheat" console, you could type something in to relocate your character. In this version, your only option would be to use the task manager to close the game without saving and revert to your last save point.

As long as you don't make the fatal mistake of saving and closing the game in an effort to escape this bug (if it will ever even be encounted in the Steam version), this game is a brilliant, procedurally generated game that will never get old.

It came free with my Windows 8 laptop, but it wasn't unlimited play, I had to have "coins" and I only got so many a week for free through developer and their little game window [rolls eyes]. Was really frustrating too, because it is actually a fun, addictive little game. So when I noticed a couple days ago that Steam had it, and that it was on sale because it is that time of the year, I jumped on it.

I was playing Tl2 for the first time today, and noticed that it is VERY similar to that, there are some differences:

-the character is a little chibi child looking thing, and you can only choose between a cat or a dog for a pet (BUT if you get lucky, you find a fish that can permanently change them, or just fish/buy fish that temporarily change them)
-this is straight up dungeon crawling, no two games/levels are the same
-no actual class picking BUT you can decide to specialize in a certain kind of weapon/magic
-single player only

Just like in Tl2, you can load your pet with things and send them to down to sell the stuff for you. Basic in game hot-buttons and controls are the same. This is basically a very simple, dungeon-crawling Tl2, if you will....but then, at the end of the day, MOST fantasy RPG are basically the same. 

This is a fun, simple, kinda cute little game, easy to pick up and play (and get lost in and loose track of the time >_< LOL) Great for anyone. I'd recommend, especially since the price is good, whether on sale or not.

8264239.review:
What's the shallowest most pointless RPG you ever played? This makes that game look like Baldurs Gate.  It's cute, but really, there's only a tiny number of quests repeated endlessly.  

It's dull repetitive shallow as a dried up puddle.   I can't think of a reason to carry on playing.

1) Only 4 quests, endlessly repeated.
2) There is no story arc, you just get a random boss to kill at the end.
3) There is only one town
4) There is only one dungeon
5) There are only about 10 quest givers max.

This may not matter to you, endless inventory management might be your idea of heaven. For me? Nah, uninstalled.

This might have been ok, 15 years ago, but really unless this has some nostalgia trip value for you, don't bother.  There are many action RPG games that offer so much more. Go play Van Helsing or Torchlight or something

8231054.review: This game is MY favorite dungeon crawler, ever. I played this when I was 10 and man was it the greatest game ever, nostalgia man. But enough remincing, obviously people want an idea what it is about. You play as a kid and his companion trying to make your "fate". The main idea is enter a dungeon with unknown dangers and make a name for yourself by coming out alive. It's a pretty simple concept really, but the execution was very, very, good. If you aren't one for old graphics and a more classic gameplay style then you might want to stay away from this one, but for $5 bucks you can't really go wrong. It should bring you hours of fun and enjoyment. If not you only lost $5 which isn't going to kill you. So get it, and besides, your friends will all be like dude what the hell is that; then you can say you are playing a classic.

8160372.review: A slayer of hours.  Its easy to get trapped into it.  Its much the same dungeon crawl as everything else, but much simpler.  Many weapons, a lot of armor, easy character customization, and simple controls.  A great game to play if your just looking to kill time for an hour or 5.  Pretty much no story line, so don't get it if your looking for some sort of RPG with an actual story.

8144125.review: This game is definitley Recommended from me... I used to play this game when I was a wee boy... so I guess you could say that I have a lot of Memories and Nolstagia.  However I do not like this game just because of that... this game has a very unqiue Medieval feel to it.  It has a very interesting Inventory UI (Which can be a bother at times but is still very inventive.)  It also has a range of different items and monsters (way to many to count!)  For the most part it seems that dungeon levels are infinte however I havent got very far yet!  This game also has a quest system which is used to gain Fame, Gold, Expierence which can be used to level up your character, and even in some cases Items, .  You also have a faithful compainion which can be a Cat or Dog depending on your preference.  They will aid in your efforts to kill Monsters and also cannot die!  You can also feed your pets fish, which will turn them into something fierce for a time.  You can also transform your pet into something permanelty (I dont know how to do this yet... but I will find out eventually.)  I quite like the idea of transforming your pet for if you are having a tough time and your normal trusty steed aint cuttin it, then you can turn him to a Unicorn or something!  The music is very pleasant and the narrators voice is pretty cool aswell.  The last thing I should mention is that... when you die there are some negative effects.  You will have to choose your fate!  And each choice you choose has a reprocussion like losing XP or Gold.  The one thing that bugs me about this game is that once you clear a Dungeon Level... there aren't any monsters that spawn in afterwards.  (What I mean is that, it would be nice that there would be a minimal amount of monsters that could still spawn so that you could level up over time without having to advance right away without having the recommended skills or power.)  Overall this game is really good, there isn't a lot of flaws with it...  I give it a 9.5 out of 10.

8141875.review:
Just as fun, and just as buggy, as the original. 
Great for nostalgia, and if it goes on good sale, worth picking up for a giggle. 
It's a mindless, perpetual randomly generating dungeon crawler. No storyline, no great mystery, just point and rapidly click mayhem.

The UI can be counterintuitive, and fishing in town can net you legendary epics, even at level one. So be aware that this game dates from 2004-2005, and has serious game balance issues and a random loot engine that is much more random than most newer games.

8125580.review: This game is such an amazing game, and although this review may be clouded with the veil of nastolga, hear me out. At the time I was younger, and only had a small, compact HP Windows XP desktop computer. It had something called the wampum store, where you'd get these purple coins to try games for free. As a kid, I would love trying out new games when time would allow, and when I found this, I fell in love. I was able to convince my father to purchase it for me and ended up putting hundreds of hours into the game. Even now, 10 years later, I still enjoy revisiting my childhood favorite and feel that, regardless of age, you will all have a great time playing it.
